channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: War in Ukraine Likely to Speed, Not Slow, Shift to Clean Energy, I.E.A. Says
item.description: While some nations are burning more coal this year in response to natural-gas shortages spurred by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, that effect is expected to be short-lived.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Martin Meissner/Associated Press
item.media:description: Sheep grazing in front of a coal-fired power plant and wind turbines near Luetzerath, Germany, in October, 2022.

item.title: Putin Wants to Divide Ukrainians. Mykolaiv Is a Test Case.
item.description: In a battered city on Ukraine’s southern coast, salt water runs from the taps and electricity is sporadic. Residents curse Russia, but also express frustration with their own leaders.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: Biden Faces New Challenges With Coalition on Ukraine Support
item.description: The domestic and international consensus has shown signs of fraying as midterm elections loom in the United States and Europeans face the prospect of a cold winter.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden met with Defense Department leaders on Wednesday as the White House signaled Russia remained committed to its war in Ukraine.

item.title: Russia Intensifies Its Propaganda Campaign Against Ukraine
item.description: A new push by the Kremlin frames the war as a counterterrorism operation and seeks to rally Russians to support the fight, officials and researchers say.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A priest blessed new military enlistees at a recruiting office in Moscow this month. By framing Ukraine as the potential nuclear aggressor, Russia can ratchet up tensions over escalating the war without incurring the wrath of its population or further undermining support for President Vladimir V. Putin.

item.title: A Rising Dollar Is Hurting Other Currencies. Central Banks are Stepping In.
item.description: The Federal Reserve’s interest rate hikes are unsettling global markets and prompting other central banks to prop up their domestic currencies.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside a securities firm in Tokyo. Last week, the Japanese yen fell to its weakest level against the dollar since 1990, down more than 23 percent for the year.

item.title: Credit Suisse Unveils Sweeping Revamp to Revive Its Fortunes
item.description: The restructuring includes shrinking its investment bank and raising $4 billion in capital from investors, including a state-owned Saudi bank.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:credit: Arnd Wiegmann/Reuters
item.media:description: Thursday’s restructuring announcement marks the latest effort by Credit Suisse — a linchpin of the Swiss banking industry for 166 years — to turn around its fortunes.

item.title: Fetterman’s Debate Showing Raises Democratic Anxieties in Senate Battle
item.description: The Democratic nominee’s performance in Pennsylvania thrust questions of health to the center of a pivotal Senate race, adding uncertainty to the contest and worrying some in his party.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Disability advocates and doctors praised Lt. Gov. John Fetterman for his debate appearance and noted that his speech did not reflect any cognitive impairment, but some Democrats worried that ordinary voters might see it differently.

item.title: Pennsylvania Voters Absorb an Unusual Oz-Fetterman Debate
item.description: In interviews, Democrats and Republicans had a range of reactions to the state’s Senate debate, including alarm, protectiveness, empathy and worry about the political implications.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck and Alyce McFadden
item.media:credit: Amanda Mustard for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I felt sorry for Fetterman,” said Deb Donahue, 68, a registered Republican and a Mehmet Oz supporter from Camp Hill, Pa. “I think he really struggled a little bit.”

item.title: Second Woman Says Walker Paid for Her to Have Abortion
item.description: The woman delivered her story anonymously in a news conference with Gloria Allred, the celebrity lawyer. The New York Times could not confirm the account.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman and Maya King
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Herschel Walker, Georgia’s Republican nominee for Senate, at a campaign event in Cordele, Ga., last week.

item.title: Texas Goes Permitless on Guns, and Police Face an Armed Public
item.description: A new law allowing people to carry handguns without a license has led to more spontaneous shootings, many in law enforcement say.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Matthew Busch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Texas is the most populous state to do away with handgun permit requirements.

item.title: Prosecutors Seek Testimony on Trump Declassifying Documents
item.description: The Justice Department is seeking to compel Kash Patel, an ally of the former president, to answer questions about assertions that material taken from the White House had been declassified.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman, Charlie Savage and Michael S. Schmidt
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump has claimed that he declassified national security documents he took from the White House.

item.title: Tech’s Biggest Companies Are Sending Worrying Signals About the Economy
item.description: A series of quarterly earnings reports is showing that even Silicon Valley’s most powerful companies are feeling the impact of inflation and rising interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Elaine Thompson/Associated Press
item.media:description: Microsoft is one of several big tech companies saying that their businesses are cooling.

item.title: Senator Robert Menendez Faces a New Federal Investigation
item.description: The inquiry comes five years after the Justice Department dropped its corruption case against Mr. Menendez, a New Jersey Democrat.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully, Benjamin Weiser and William K. Rashbaum

item.title: Prince Harry’s Memoir Is Due in January. How Explosive Will It Be?
item.description: The memoir is expected to be a best seller, but after the queen’s death, some royal experts and industry executives say the project has become risky for Harry.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Stephan De Sakutin
item.media:description: Prince Harry struck a competitive, and lucrative, multi-book deal that had as its main attraction a memoir which he said would be a frank accounting of his life. Since the queen’s death, however, criticizing the royal family has become a riskier proposition.

item.title: The Dos and Don’ts of Living in a Haunted House
item.description: Many Americans believe that their home is inhabited by ghosts, a conviction that researchers attribute to the rise of paranormal-related media, a decline in religious beliefs and the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Anna Kodé
item.media:credit: Eamon Queeney for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shane Booth in his dining room where he said the bulk of the paranormal activity happens at his home in Benson, N.C.

item.title: How Does Britain’s Conservative Government End? Maybe With a Labour Rout.
item.description: After 12 years in opposition, Labour finally looks ready to seize the moment.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Hanley
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: The British Labour Party leader, Keir Starmer, and the deputy leader, Angela Rayner, at the party’s annual conference in Liverpool last month.

item.title: Many Russians Are Anxious and Afraid, but They Still Support Putin
item.description: It’s not as strange as it might seem.
item.dc:creator: Gulnaz Sharafutdinova
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman holding a poster that says “U.S., NATO, Hands Off Ukraine” in front of the United States Embassy in Moscow.

item.title: Fetterman vs. Oz Is Not Really Fetterman vs. Oz
item.description: About that Pennsylvania debate …
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins
item.media:credit: Tom Gralish/The Philadelphia Inquirer, via Associated Press

item.title: Putin Is Onto Us
item.description: When it comes to energy, the West wants five incompatible things at once.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Gavriil Grigorov

item.title: An Alternate History of the 2022 Midterms
item.description: In the campaign’s final days, Democratic strategists are already back-seat driving, second-guessing and what-iffing.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Bernie Sanders wrote recently that “while the abortion issue must remain on the front burner, it would be political malpractice for Democrats to ignore the state of the economy.”

item.title: Not the Daughter She Wanted
item.description: When it comes to whom she loves, an immigrant daughter can’t make her mother happy. But she holds on to hope, as her mother always taught her to do.
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: When You’re Sick at Home
item.description: Your guide to eating well, even when you’re feeling low.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Richardson
item.media:credit: Ben Russell for The New York Times
item.media:description: The smoked brisket pho from Lucy’s Vietnamese in Brooklyn makes for a perfect recovery meal.

item.title: Do You Have Messy Handwriting? We Want to See It.
item.description: Is your penmanship a mess? Can you often not read your own handwriting? Share something you wrote and later found hard to decipher.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Paoletto
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Kanye West Is Escorted From Skechers Offices, Company Says
item.description: The footwear company said Mr. West, also known as Ye, had been “engaged in unauthorized filming” at one of its corporate offices in Los Angeles.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Julien De Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Kanye West in Paris this month.

item.title: Garland Formally Bars Justice Dept. From Seizing Reporters’ Records
item.description: The rule codifies and expands a policy he issued in 2021, after it came to light that the Trump administration had secretly gone after records of reporters for The Times, The Washington Post and CNN.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The changes, Attorney General Merrick B. Garland said, “recognize the crucial role that a free and independent press plays in our democracy.”

item.title: Gene Treatment for Rare Epilepsy Causes Brain Side Effect in 2 Children
item.description: The side effect, a buildup of fluid in the brain, led to the death of one of the children and presents a grave setback for a class of personalized medicine.
item.dc:creator: Erika Check Hayden

item.title: A 23-Million-Year-Old Fossil Is Carried Away by Parties Unknown
item.description: The whale fossil, a cherished local attraction, was taken from a riverbank in broad daylight by two men with a rock saw and chisel, residents say.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Bryan Le Dantec /Getty Images
item.media:description: The town of Westport, on New Zealand’s remote West Coast, about 60 miles from where the fossil was taken.

item.title: Do Statins Increase the Risk of Diabetes?
item.description: These cholesterol-lowering medications have gotten a bad rap. Here’s why.
item.dc:creator: Jyoti Madhusoodanan
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Do Antidepressants Work for Severe PMS?
item.description: Premenstrual dysphoric disorder, or PMDD, is an extreme and often debilitating form of PMS that can be tricky to manage. Here’s what treatments work.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Rabkin Peachman
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Are Earbuds Damaging My Hearing?
item.description: And if so, are they more harmful than other headphone styles?
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Night Sweats Causes: Experts Explain Why You Sweat In Your Sleep
item.description: There are many possible reasons you might wake up in a pool of perspiration. Here’s how to tell when it should be cause for concern.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Celiac Disease Treatment: Are We Close to a Cure?
item.description: Recent advances in understanding the condition have brought a surge of potential therapies to the drug development pipeline.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: This Thanksgiving, Make a Jell-O Salad Instead of Cranberry Sauce
item.description: This throwback is good enough to replace the canned stuff.
item.dc:creator: Eric Kim
item.media:credit: Chris Simpson for The New York Times. Food stylist: Maggie Ruggiero. Prop stylist: Sophia Pappas.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
